data-node-id="rjabsj"></div></div></div></div><div class="GridWrapper-cAzTTK sjrqk grid grid-margins grid-items-2 ArticlePageChunksGrid-hfxaau eSqXkM grid-layout--adrail narrow wide-adrail"><div class="GridItem-buujkM stRKV grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class="BodyWrapper-kufPGa dYWmGR body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p class="paywall">In fact, even when GiveWell reports harmful side effects, it downplays and elides them. One of its current <a data-offer-url="https://www.givewell.org/charities/new-incentives" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.givewell.org/charities/new-incentives"}" href="https://www.givewell.org/charities/new-incentives" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">top charities</a> sends money into dangerous regions of Northern Nigeria, to pay mothers to have their children vaccinated. In a <a data-offer-url="https://www.givewell.org/charities/new-incentives#Security_threats_to_staff" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.givewell.org/charities/new-incentives#Security_threats_to_staff"}" href="https://www.givewell.org/charities/new-incentives#Security_threats_to_staff" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">subsection</a> of GiveWell’s analysis of the charity, you’ll find reports of armed men attacking locations where the vaccination money is kept—including one report of a bandit who killed two people and kidnapped two children while looking for the charity’s money. You might think that GiveWell would immediately insist on independent investigations into how often those kinds of incidents happen. Yet even the deaths it already knows about <a href="https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZrQNpRuxuym7vJNmG-W_8lUTUuW_upDspFSHVOxIzZ4/edit#gid=1176773164">appear nowhere in its calculations</a> on the effects of the charity.</p><div data-attr-viewport-monitor="inline-recirc" class="inline-recirc-wrapper inline-recirc-observer-target-5 viewport-monitor-anchor"></div><p class="paywall">And more broadly, GiveWell still doesn’t factor in many well-known negative effects of aid. Studies find that when charities hire health workers away from their government jobs, this can <a href="https://www.nber.org/system/files/working_papers/w26928/w26928.pdf">increase infant mortality</a>; that aid coming into a poor country can <a data-offer-url="https://www.aeaweb.org/articles?id=10.1257/aer.104.6.1833" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.aeaweb.org/articles?id=10.1257/aer.104.6.1833"}" href="https://www.aeaweb.org/articles?id=10.1257/aer.104.6.1833" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">increase deadly attacks by armed insurgents</a>; and much more. GiveWell might try to plead that these negative effects are hard to calculate. Yet when it calculates benefits, it is willing to put numbers on all sorts of <a data-offer-url="https://blog.givewell.org/2018/02/13/revisiting-leverage/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://blog.givewell.org/2018/02/13/revisiting-leverage/"}" href="https://blog.givewell.org/2018/02/13/revisiting-leverage/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">hard-to-know things</a>.</p><p class="paywall">It looks very much like GiveWell is trying to skirt its reputation for unsentimental, computerlike calculation. If probabilities of benefits add up by fractions, then probabilities of harms must rack up too. In a comment to WIRED, GiveWell CEO Elie Hassenfeld said the organization “does tens of thousands of hours of research every year” so that “donors who want to do as much good as possible can make informed decisions on where to give.” But those donors could be far better informed. Think of a drug company that’s unwilling to report data on harmful side effects, and when pressed merely expresses confidence that its products are “overall beneficial.” GiveWell is like that—except that the benefits it reports may go to some poor people, while the harms it omits may fall on others. Today GiveWell’s <a data-offer-url="https://www.givewell.org/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.givewell.org/"}" href="https://www.givewell.org/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">front page</a> advertises only the number of lives it thinks it has saved. A more honest front page would also display the number of deaths it believes it has caused.</p><p class="paywall">I finished up “Poverty Is No Pond” and added one more point, which I’ve come to think is the most important to make to EAs: Extreme poverty is not about me, and it’s not about you. It’s about people facing daily challenges that most of us can hardly imagine. If we decide to intervene in poor people's lives, we should do so responsibly—ideally by shifting our power to them and being accountable for our actions.</p><p class="paywall"><span class="lead-in-text-callout">After that, I</span> figured that EA would come to grief, and I moved on to other work. What I didn’t see coming was the pitchman and the billionaires.</p><p class="paywall">The pitchman was <a href="https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2022/08/15/the-reluctant-prophet-of-effective-altruism">Will MacAskill</a>, another young Oxford EA with a PhD in philosophy. In <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/10/08/business/effective-altruism-elon-musk.html">2012</a>, MacAskill had been trawling elite American universities, looking to catch future EA funders. At MIT he met an undergraduate physics major with an interest in animal welfare, Sam Bankman-Fried. MacAskill told SBF that the most good he could do was actually to go into finance, get filthy rich, and give big money to the cause. “<a data-offer-url="https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/3Ss29ihXsBb8tuoxK/earning-to-give-vs-altruistic-career-choice-revisited" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/3Ss29ihXsBb8tuoxK/earning-to-give-vs-altruistic-career-choice-revisited"}" href="https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/3Ss29ihXsBb8tuoxK/earning-to-give-vs-altruistic-career-choice-revisited" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">Earning to give</a>,” he called it. It was the perfect net to catch that particular fish.</p></div></div></div><div class="GridItem-buujkM fVLMby grid--item grid-layout__aside"><div class="StickyBoxWrapper-jfYBuk fifekH sticky-box"><div data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.effectivealtruism.org/doing-good-better"}" href="https://www.effectivealtruism.org/doing-good-better" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">pitch book for EA</a>. The book tells you that you can be a hero by giving to charities in the EA way—you’ll be like the guy who pulls people from a burning building, it says, or even like Oskar Schindler. Your heroic donations can do “a <em>tremendous</em> amount of good.”</p><p class="paywall">MacAskill admits that many experts are skeptics about aid. Yet he gushes that aid has been “incredibly beneficial”:</p><blockquote class="BlockquoteEmbedWrapper-sc-SdiGL gzzTVu paywall blockquote-embed"><div class="BlockquoteEmbedContent-esRbGs dqgvoS blockquote-embed__content"><p>The claim that there is “not much to show for [aid]” is simply false. Even among the “bottom billion”—the population of countries that have experienced the weakest economic growth over the last few decades—quality of life has increased dramatically. In 1950, life expectancy in sub-Saharan Africa was just 36.7 years. Now it’s 56 years, a gain of almost 50% … In reality, a tiny amount of aid has been spent, and there have been dramatic increases in the welfare of the world’s poorest people.</p></div></blockquote><p class="paywall">Now this is pure hooey. Even aid’s biggest boosters would cringe at the implication that aid had caused a 50 percent increase in sub-Saharan life expectancies. And what follows this astonishing statement is a tangle of qualifications and irrelevancies trailing off into the footnotes. To anyone who knows even a little about aid, it’s like MacAskill has tattooed “Not Serious” on his forehead.</p><div data-attr-viewport-monitor="inline-recirc" class="inline-recirc-wrapper inline-recirc-observer-target-6 viewport-monitor-anchor"></div><p class="paywall">He then makes his pitch for specific interventions in poor countries. He pours scorn on the last “thing” in aid that was going to solve everything—microcredit. He then pushes the latest thing, which at that time was giving deworming pills to poor children. You can guess what happened after his book was published. The same research organization that MacAskill singled out for its rigorous evaluations released <a data-offer-url="https://www.cochrane.org/CD000371/INFECTN_deworming-school-children-low-and-middle-income-countries" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.cochrane.org/CD000371/INFECTN_deworming-school-children-low-and-middle-income-countries"}" href="https://www.cochrane.org/CD000371/INFECTN_deworming-school-children-low-and-middle-income-countries" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">a report</a> finding no proof of benefits from <a data-offer-url="https://www.cambridge.org/core/services/aop-cambridge-core/content/view/F53A81E632335EB38F8754051D79C547/S0021932016000171a.pdf" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.cambridge.org/core/services/aop-cambridge-core/content/view/F53A81E632335EB38F8754051D79C547/S0021932016000171a.pdf"}" href="https://www.cambridge.org/core/services/aop-cambridge-core/content/view/F53A81E632335EB38F8754051D79C547/S0021932016000171a.pdf" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">mass deworming</a>. GiveWell, which had given a deworming charity its top rating for almost a decade, <a data-offer-url="https://www.givewell.org/charities/deworm-world-initiative/August-2022-version" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.givewell.org/charities/deworm-world-initiative/August-2022-version"}" href="https://www.givewell.org/charities/deworm-world-initiative/August-2022-version" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">down-rated it</a> and now no longer accepts donations for it.</p><aside aria-hidden="true" class="PullQuoteEmbedWrapper-sc-EoVjf kgVYDs"><div class="PullQuoteDecorativeBorder-sc-iUyOLj jyfYFL"></div><div class="PullQuoteEmbedContent-sc-kTcfhx dzGCEG"><p class="paywall">“As I use the term,” MacAskill says, “<em>altruism</em> simply means improving the lives of others.” No competent philosopher could have written that sentence. Their flesh would have melted off and the bones dissolved before their fingers hit the keyboard.</p></div></aside><p class="paywall">In making his pitch to donors, MacAskill left out many of the possible impacts of the charities that “save lives”—he made the drug commercial without the part about all the side effects. Remember the imaginary story about the Chinese trillionaires and kids getting sick from pills their parents never consented to? That story was based on <a data-offer-url="https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-biosocial-science/article/rumours-riots-and-the-rejection-of-mass-drug-administration-for-the-treatment-of-schistosomiasis-in-morogoro-tanzania/7CA864E87B159245C14BCBF31BC647B1" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-biosocial-science/article/rumours-riots-and-the-rejection-of-mass-drug-administration-for-the-treatment-of-schistosomiasis-in-morogoro-tanzania/7CA864E87B159245C14BCBF31BC647B1"}" href="https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-biosocial-science/article/rumours-riots-and-the-rejection-of-mass-drug-administration-for-the-treatment-of-schistosomiasis-in-morogoro-tanzania/7CA864E87B159245C14BCBF31BC647B1" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">what actually happened in Tanzania</a> when a mass deworming initiative—a kind of aid MacAskill promoted—was rolled out. Some angry parents rioted when they discovered what had been done to their children.</p><p class="paywall">For a philosopher to talk applesauce about aid is not so surprising. For a philosopher to peddle bad philosophy is something else.</p><p class="paywall">Let me give a sense of how bad MacAskill’s philosophizing is. Words are the tools of the trade for philosophers, and we’re pretty obsessive about defining them. So you might think that the philosopher of effective altruism could tell us what “altruism” is. MacAskill says,</p></div></div></div><div class="GridItem-buujkM fVLMby grid--item grid-layout__aside"><div class="StickyBoxWrapper-jfYBuk fifekH sticky-box"><div class="StickyBoxPrimary-dzWDWL cdhYoN data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><blockquote class="BlockquoteEmbedWrapper-sc-SdiGL gzzTVu paywall blockquote-embed"><div class="BlockquoteEmbedContent-esRbGs dqgvoS blockquote-embed__content"><p>I want to be clear on what [“altruism”] means. As I use the term, <em>altruism</em> simply means improving the lives of others.</p></div></blockquote><p class="paywall">No competent philosopher could have written that sentence. Their flesh would have melted off and the bones dissolved before their fingers hit the keyboard. What “altruism” really means, of course, is acting on a selfless concern for the well-being of others—the <em>why</em> and the <em>how</em> are part of the concept. But for MacAskill, a totally selfish person could be an “altruist” if they improve others’ lives without meaning to. Even Sweeney Todd could be an altruist by MacAskill’s definition, as he improves the lives of the many Londoners who love his meat pies, made from the Londoners he’s killed.</p><p class="paywall">And then there’s MacAskill’s philosophy of how to give credit, which is a big part of how he persuades people to give to EA charities. The measure of what you achieve, MacAskill writes, is the difference you make in the world: “the difference between what happens as a result of your actions and what would have happened anyway.” If you donate enough money to a charity that gives out insecticide-treated bed nets, MacAskill says, you will “save the life” of someone who otherwise would have died of malaria—just as surely as if you ran into a burning building and dragged a young child to safety.</p><p class="paywall">But let’s picture that person you’ve supposedly rescued from death in MacAskill’s account—say it’s a young Malawian boy. Do you really deserve all the credit for “saving his life”? Didn’t the people who first developed the bed nets also “make a difference” in preventing his malaria? More importantly, what about his mother? She chose to trust the aid workers and use the net they handed to her, which <a data-offer-url="https://www.givewell.org/how-much-does-it-cost-to-save-a-life" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.givewell.org/how-much-does-it-cost-to-save-a-life"}" href="https://www.givewell.org/how-much-does-it-cost-to-save-a-life" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">not all parents do</a>. Doesn’t her agency matter—doesn’t her choice to use the net “make a difference” in what happens to her child? Wouldn’t it in fact be more accurate for MacAskill to say that your donation offers this mother the opportunity to “save the life” of her own child?</p><p class="paywall">Success has many parents, as the old saw says, while failure is an orphan. But all right, let’s say that MacAskill is right and each person <em>is</em> responsible for everything that wouldn’t have happened without what they did. Then it would follow that each person is responsible for the bad as well as the good. We know that MacAskill persuaded Sam Bankman-Fried to go into finance instead of into animal welfare. By his own theory, MacAskill would then be responsible for what SBF did in finance. So MacAskill should be demanding to go to prison along with SBF, right?</p><div data-attr-viewport-monitor="inline-recirc" class="inline-recirc-wrapper inline-recirc-observer-target-7 viewport-monitor-anchor"></div><p class="paywall"><span class="lead-in-text-callout">None of this</span> tomfoolery would matter if it weren’t for the tech billionaires. The EAs spoke in a language that came naturally to them.</p></div></div></div><div class="GridItem-buujkM fVLMby grid--item grid-layout__aside"><div class="StickyBoxWrapper-jfYBuk fifekH class="GridItem-buujkM stRKV grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class="BodyWrapper-kufPGa dYWmGR body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p class="paywall">The core of EA’s philosophy is a mental tool that venture capitalists use every day. The tool is “<a data-offer-url="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/e/expected-value.asp" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.investopedia.com/terms/e/expected-value.asp"}" href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/e/expected-value.asp" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">expected value</a>” thinking, which you may remember from Economics 101. Say you’re trying to maximize returns on $100. You guess that some stock has a 60 percent chance of gaining $10 and a 40 percent chance of losing $10. Multiplying through, you find that this stock has an expected value of $102. You then repeat these calculations for the other stocks you could buy. The most rational gamble is to buy the stock with the highest expected value.</p><aside aria-hidden="true" class="PullQuoteEmbedWrapper-sc-EoVjf kgVYDs"><div class="PullQuoteDecorativeBorder-sc-iUyOLj jyfYFL"></div><div class="PullQuoteEmbedContent-sc-kTcfhx dzGCEG"><p class="paywall">Effective altruism started to synergize with adjacent subcultures, like the transhumanists (wannabe cyborgs) and the rationalists (think “Mensa with orgies”). Suddenly EA was everywhere. It was a thing.</p></div></aside><p class="paywall">Expected value thinking can be applied to any choice, and it needn’t be selfish. You can aim at the most value-for-you, or the most value-for-the-universe—the method is the same. What EA pushes is expected value as a life hack for morality. Want to make the world better? GiveWell has done the calculations on how to rescue poor humans. A few clicks and you’re done: Move fast and save people. EA even set up a <a data-offer-url="https://80000hours.org/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://80000hours.org/"}" href="https://80000hours.org/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">guidance counseling service</a> that championed the earning-to-give strategy. EA showed math-talented students that getting really rich in finance would let them donate lots of money to EA. A huge income for yourself can SAVE HUNDREDS OF LIVES.</p><p class="paywall">Expected value thinking can be useful in finance. But what if someone actually hacked their whole life with it? What if someone tried to calculate the expected value of every choice they made, every minute of every day?</p><p class="paywall">That’s Sam Bankman-Fried. SBF was easy for EA to recruit because its life hack was already his mindset. As <a data-offer-url="https://wwnorton.com/books/9781324074335" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://wwnorton.com/books/9781324074335"}" href="https://wwnorton.com/books/9781324074335" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">Michael Lewis</a> writes, with every choice SBF thinks in terms of maximizing expected value. And his calculations are “rational” in being free from emotional connections to other people. EA encourages people to be more “rational” like this. SBF is a natural.</p><p class="paywall">To get yourself into SBF’s mindset, consider whether you would play the following godlike game for real. In this game, there’s a 51 percent chance that you create another Earth but also a 49 percent chance that you destroy all human life. If you’re using expected value thinking, and if you think that human life has positive value, you must play this game. <a data-offer-url="https://conversationswithtyler.com/episodes/sam-bankman-fried/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://conversationswithtyler.com/episodes/sam-bankman-fried/"}" href="https://conversationswithtyler.com/episodes/sam-bankman-fried/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">SBF said he would play this game</a>. And he said he would keep playing it, double or nothing, over and over again. With expected value thinking, the slightly higher chance of creating more value requires endlessly risking the annihilation of humanity.</p><p class="paywall">Expected value is why SBF constantly played video games, even <a href="https://www.latimes.com/business/story/2023-11-08/column-silicon-valley-vcs-wanted-to-believe-sbfs-lies-now-they-want-you-to-believe-their-excuses">while Zooming with investors</a>. He calculated that he could add the pleasure of the game to the value of the calls. The key to understanding SBF is that he plays people like they’re games too. With his long-suffering EA girlfriend, her expected value went up when he wanted sex and then down right afterward (again according to Lewis). This is the perfection of the EA philosophy: Maximize the value of the use of any given resource. And aren’t other people resources that can produce value?</p><p class="paywall">After all the media, the biographies, the trial, and the sentencing, people have different reads on Sam Bankman-Fried. <a href="https://fortune.com/2022/11/15/what-is-effective-altruism-sam-bankman-fried-wealth-career/">Is he a selfish villain or an unlucky saint?</a> Was he really aiming at maximum value-for the-universe? Or maximum value-for-Sam?</p><div data-attr-viewport-monitor="inline-recirc" class="inline-recirc-wrapper inline-recirc-observer-target-8 viewport-monitor-anchor"></div><p class="paywall">I suspect that, in his mind, the two aims converged. If you’re earning-to-give, you should maximize your wealth. And if you think each moment should be optimized for profit, you’ll never choose to spend resources on boring grown-up things like auditors and a chief financial officer. For SBF, good-for-me-now and good-for-everyone-always started to merge into one.</p></div></div></div><div class="GridItem-buujkM fVLMby grid--item grid-layout__aside"><div data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p class="paywall">And yet, as we know, SBF consistently made terrible choices, even beyond the way he ran his company. During his detention, prosecutors allege, he made the disastrous decision to <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2023/07/20/technology/ftx-caroline-ellison-bankman-fried.html">leak his girlfriend’s diaries</a> to the press. The judge, who anyone could see was not playing, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2023/08/11/technology/sam-bankman-fried-jail.html">threw him in jail</a>. At the trial, he insisted on testifying and was predictably <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/audio/2023-12-15/bloomberg-law-sbf-s-lawyer-says-he-was-the-worst-witness">abysmal on the stand</a>. His calculations seemed cockeyed throughout.</p><p class="paywall">Here we need to jump from Econ to Psych 101. As Daniel Kahneman says, “<a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/steveforbes/2013/01/24/nobel-prize-winner-daniel-kahneman-lessons-from-hitlers-ss-and-the-danger-in-trusting-your-gut/?sh=764f3a57156e">We think, each of us, that we’re much more rational than we are.</a>” When doing expected value thinking, the potential for rationalization and self-serving bias are immense. In the trial, SBF’s self-deceptions finally hit reality. The jury found him <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2023-11-03/speedy-bankman-fried-verdict-is-unusal-for-big-white-collar-case">obviously guilty</a> of seven counts of fraud and conspiracy. He’s now facing accountability for what can only be called his irrationality. The actual value of all his expected value calculations turned out to be a 25-year prison sentence.</p><p class="paywall">When SBF’s frauds were first revealed, the EA philosophers <a data-offer-url="https://twitter.com/willmacaskill/status/1591218014707671040?lang=en" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://twitter.com/willmacaskill/status/1591218014707671040?lang=en"}" href="https://twitter.com/willmacaskill/status/1591218014707671040?lang=en" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">tried mightily</a> to put as much distance as they could between themselves and him. Yet young EAs should think carefully about how much their leaders’ reasoning shared the flaws of Sam Bankman-Fried’s.</p><p class="paywall">With the philosophers too, good-for-others kept merging into good-for-me. SBF bought his team <a href="https://www.reuters.com/technology/exclusive-bankman-frieds-ftx-parents-bought-bahamas-property-worth-121-mln-2022-11-22/">extravagant condos</a> in the Bahamas; the EAs bought their crew a <a data-offer-url="https://www.openphilanthropy.org/grants/effective-ventures-foundation-uk-event-venue/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.openphilanthropy.org/grants/effective-ventures-foundation-uk-event-venue/"}" href="https://www.openphilanthropy.org/grants/effective-ventures-foundation-uk-event-venue/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">medieval English manor</a> as well as a <a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/sarahemerson/2023/02/28/effective-altruism-linked-group-used-millions-donated-by-ftx-to-buy-a-czech-castle/?sh=bc368536bafd">Czech castle</a>. The EAs <a data-offer-url="https://www.truthdig.com/articles/effective-altruism-is-a-welter-of-fraud-lies-exploitation-and-eugenic-fantasies/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.truthdig.com/articles/effective-altruism-is-a-welter-of-fraud-lies-exploitation-and-eugenic-fantasies/"}" href="https://www.truthdig.com/articles/effective-altruism-is-a-welter-of-fraud-lies-exploitation-and-eugenic-fantasies/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">flew private</a> and ate <a href="https://time.com/6262810/sam-bankman-fried-effective-altruism-alameda-ftx/">$500-a-head dinners</a>, and MacAskill’s second book had a lavish <a data-offer-url="https://www.truthdig.com/articles/the-grift-brothers/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.truthdig.com/articles/the-grift-brothers/"}" href="https://www.truthdig.com/articles/the-grift-brothers/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">promotion campaign</a> that got him the cover story of <em>Time</em> magazine. For philosophers who thought themselves bringing such extraordinary goodness to the world, these personal benefits must have seemed easy to justify. Philosophy gives no immunity against self-deceit.</p><p class="paywall"><span class="lead-in-text-callout">While SBF’s money</span> was still coming in, EA greatly <a data-offer-url="https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/GZn2xGR37or7N9zLm/many-groups-metrics-have-grown-by-100-to-400-in-the-past" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/GZn2xGR37or7N9zLm/many-groups-metrics-have-grown-by-100-to-400-in-the-past"}" href="https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/GZn2xGR37or7N9zLm/many-groups-metrics-have-grown-by-100-to-400-in-the-past" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">expanded</a> its recruitment of college students. GiveWell’s Karnofsky moved to an EA philanthropy that gives out <a data-offer-url="https://www.openphilanthropy.org/research/our-progress-in-2022-and-plans-for-2023/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.openphilanthropy.org/research/our-progress-in-2022-and-plans-for-2023/"}" href="https://www.openphilanthropy.org/research/our-progress-in-2022-and-plans-for-2023/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">hundreds of millions of dollars a year</a> and staffed up institutes with portentous names like <a data-offer-url="https://www.openphilanthropy.org/?s=global+priorities" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.openphilanthropy.org/?s=global+priorities"}" href="https://www.openphilanthropy.org/?s=global+priorities" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">Global Priorities</a> and <a data-offer-url="https://www.openphilanthropy.org/?s=future+of+humanity+" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.openphilanthropy.org/?s=future+of+humanity+"}" href="https://www.openphilanthropy.org/?s=future+of+humanity+" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">The Future of Humanity</a>. Effective altruism started to synergize with adjacent subcultures, like the <a href="https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/social-sciences/transhumanism">transhumanists</a> (wannabe cyborgs) and the <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2023/10/08/technology/prediction-markets-manifold-manifest.html">rationalists</a> (think “Mensa with orgies”). <a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/jamesbroughel/2023/11/20/effective-altruism-contributed-to-the-fiasco-at-openai/?sh=39eb864e6c2b">EAs filled the board</a> of one of the Big Tech companies (the one they later almost crashed). Suddenly, EA was everywhere. It was a thing.</p><p class="paywall">This was also a paradoxical time for EA’s leadership. While their following was growing ever larger, their thinking was looking even soggier.</p><p class="paywall">You can see this by what GiveWell became. During the flush times, the <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20220101041740/https:/www.givewell.org/">pitch pages</a> of its website juiced donors by advertising its “in-depth evaluations” of “highly effective charities” which do “an incredible amount of good.” The pitch came with precise figures: the cost to “save a life” (now up to <a data-offer-url="https://www.givewell.org/charities/top-charities/November-2021-version" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.givewell.org/charities/top-charities/November-2021-version"}" href="https://www.givewell.org/charities/top-charities/November-2021-version" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">$3,500</a>) and the total lives GiveWell has “saved” (now up to <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20211130043650/https://www.givewell.org/">75,000</a>). But in the sub-subpages, it turned out that these precise figures were based on very weak evidence and endless hedging.</p><aside aria-hidden="true" class="PullQuoteEmbedWrapper-sc-EoVjf kgVYDs"><div class="PullQuoteDecorativeBorder-sc-iUyOLj jyfYFL"></div><div class="PullQuoteEmbedContent-sc-kTcfhx dzGCEG"><p class="paywall">What’s the point in deworming a few hundred kids in Tanzania when you could pour that money into astronautical research instead and help millions of unborn souls to escape Earth and live joyfully among the stars?</p></div></aside><p class="paywall">For example, remember that deworming charity that was one of GiveWell’s top recommendations for almost a decade (until, in 2022, it wasn’t)? GiveWell’s “in-depth research” found it “highly effective.” Yet what was GiveWell’s “<a data-offer-url="https://www.givewell.org/charities/deworm-world-initiative/supplementary-information#Testimony_of_a_government_official" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.givewell.org/charities/deworm-world-initiative/supplementary-information#Testimony_of_a_government_official"}" href="https://www.givewell.org/charities/deworm-world-initiative/supplementary-information#Testimony_of_a_government_official" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">strongest piece of evidence</a>” that the charity improved on what local governments were doing anyway? In the fine print, that piece of evidence turns out to be a single interview with a low-level official in one of the five countries where the charity worked—that’s it.</p><div data-attr-viewport-monitor="inline-recirc" class="inline-recirc-wrapper inline-recirc-observer-target-9 viewport-monitor-anchor"></div><p class="paywall">Then there’s the hedging. GiveWell’s pitch page projects absolute confidence in its exact numbers; the nested links tell a different story. In the fine print, the calculations are hedged with phrases like “<a data-offer-url="https://blog.givewell.org/2018/02/13/revisiting-leverage/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://blog.givewell.org/2018/02/13/revisiting-leverage/"}" href="https://blog.givewell.org/2018/02/13/revisiting-leverage/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">very rough guess</a>,” “<a data-offer-url="https://www.givewell.org/how-we-work/our-criteria/cost-effectiveness" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.givewell.org/how-we-work/our-criteria/cost-effectiveness"}" href="https://www.givewell.org/how-we-work/our-criteria/cost-effectiveness" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">very limited data</a>,” “<a data-offer-url="https://blog.givewell.org/2018/02/13/revisiting-leverage/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://blog.givewell.org/2018/02/13/revisiting-leverage/"}" href="https://blog.givewell.org/2018/02/13/revisiting-leverage/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">we don’t feel confident</a>,” “<a data-offer-url="https://www.givewell.org/charities/deworm-world-initiative/supplementary-information" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.givewell.org/charities/deworm-world-initiative/supplementary-information"}" href="https://www.givewell.org/charities/deworm-world-initiative/supplementary-information" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">we are highly uncertain</a>,” “<a data-offer-url="https://www.givewell.org/how-we-work/our-criteria/cost-effectiveness/comparing-moral-weights" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.givewell.org/how-we-work/our-criteria/cost-effectiveness/comparing-moral-weights"}" href="https://www.givewell.org/how-we-work/our-criteria/cost-effectiveness/comparing-moral-weights" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">subjective and uncertain inputs</a>.” These pages also say that “<a data-offer-url="https://www.givewell.org/how-we-work/our-criteria/cost-effectiveness/cost-effectiveness-models" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.givewell.org/how-we-work/our-criteria/cost-effectiveness/cost-effectiveness-models"}" href="https://www.givewell.org/how-we-work/our-criteria/cost-effectiveness/cost-effectiveness-models" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">we consider our cost-effectiveness numbers to be extremely rough</a>,” and that these numbers “<a data-offer-url="https://www.givewell.org/international/technical/programs/new-incentives#How_cost-effective_is_it" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.givewell.org/international/technical/programs/new-incentives#How_cost-effective_is_it"}" href="https://www.givewell.org/international/technical/programs/new-incentives#How_cost-effective_is_it" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">should not be taken literally</a>.” What’s going on?</p></div></div></div><div class="GridItem-buujkM fVLMby grid--item grid-layout__aside"><div class="StickyBoxWrapper-jfYBuk fifekH sticky-box"><div class="StickyBoxPrimary-dzWDWL cdhYoN data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p class="paywall">MacAskill’s <a data-offer-url="https://whatweowethefuture.com/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://whatweowethefuture.com/"}" href="https://whatweowethefuture.com/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">second book</a> was also what the Brits call fur-coat-and-no-knickers and was even more shameless than his first. (The first book tells you where to give your money; the second tells you how to run most of your life.) Up front, MacAskill says that he has “relied heavily on an extensive team of consultants and research assistants” and that the book represents more than a decade of full-time work, including almost two years of fact-checking.</p><p class="paywall">This bravado carries over into the blunt advice that MacAskill gives throughout the book. For instance, are you concerned about the environment? Recycling or changing your diet should not be your priority, he says; you can be “radically more impactful.” By giving $3,000 to a lobbying group called Clean Air Task Force (CATF), MacAskill declares, you can reduce carbon emissions by a massive 3,000 metric tons per year. That sounds great.</p><p class="paywall">Friends, here’s where those numbers <a data-offer-url="https://www.founderspledge.com/downloads/fp-climate-change" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.founderspledge.com/downloads/fp-climate-change"}" href="https://www.founderspledge.com/downloads/fp-climate-change" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">come from</a>. MacAskill cites one of Ord’s <a data-offer-url="https://oxford.academia.edu/JohnHalstead/CurriculumVitae" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://oxford.academia.edu/JohnHalstead/CurriculumVitae"}" href="https://oxford.academia.edu/JohnHalstead/CurriculumVitae" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">research assistants</a>—a recent PhD with no obvious experience in climate, energy, or policy—who wrote a report on climate charities. The assistant chose the <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/08/16/opinion/climate-inflation-reduction-act.html">controversial “carbon capture and storage”</a> technology as his top climate intervention and found that CATF had lobbied for it. The research assistant asked folks at CATF, some of their funders, and some unnamed sources how successful they thought CATF’s best lobbying campaigns had been. He combined these interviews with lots of “best guesses” and “back of the envelope” calculations, using a method he was “not completely confident” in, to come up with dollar figures for emissions reductions. That’s it.</p><p class="paywall">Strong hyping of precise numbers based on weak evidence and lots of hedging and fudging. EAs appoint themselves experts on everything based on a sophomore’s understanding of rationality and the world. And the way they test their reasoning—debating other EAs via <a data-offer-url="https://finmoorhouse.com/writing/ea-blogs/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://finmoorhouse.com/writing/ea-blogs/"}" href="https://finmoorhouse.com/writing/ea-blogs/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">blog posts</a> and <a data-offer-url="https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/"}" href="https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">chatboards</a>—often makes it worse. Here, the basic laws of sociology kick in. With so little feedback from outside, the views that prevail in-group are typically the views that are stated the most confidently by the EA with higher status. EAs rediscovered groupthink.</p><p class="paywall">At some point, the money took over. The philosophers invited the tech billionaires to dance. Then the billionaires started calling the tunes.</p><p class="paywall"><span class="lead-in-text-callout">I suspect that</span> the tech billionaires didn’t want to be heroes merely by saving individual lives. That’s just what firemen do; that’s just what Spider-Man does. The billionaires wanted to be heroes who saved the whole human race. That’s what Iron Man does. SBF was never really interested in bed nets. His <a href="https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2022/08/15/the-reluctant-prophet-of-effective-altruism">all-in commitment</a> was to a philosophy of creating maximum value for the universe, until it ends.</p><p class="paywall">So that became the philosophers’ goal too. They started to emphasize a philosophy, <a data-offer-url="https://www.williammacaskill.com/longtermism" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.williammacaskill.com/longtermism"}" href="https://www.williammacaskill.com/longtermism" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">longtermism</a>, that holds the moral worth of unborn generations equal to the worth of living ones. And actually, unborn generations could be worth <em>a lot more</em> than we are today, given population growth. What’s the point in deworming a few hundred kids in Tanzania when you could pour that money into astronautical research instead and help millions of unborn souls to escape Earth and live joyfully among the stars?</p></div></div></div><div class="GridItem-buujkM fVLMby grid--item grid-layout__aside"><div class="StickyBoxWrapper-jfYBuk fifekH sticky-box"><div class="StickyBoxPrimary-dzWDWL class="GridItem-buujkM stRKV grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class="BodyWrapper-kufPGa dYWmGR body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p class="paywall">Conveniently for both the billionaires and the philosophers, longtermism removed any risk of being proved wrong. No more annoyances like bad press for the charities you’ve recommended. Now they could brag that they were guarding the galaxy, with no fear of any back talk from the people of the 22nd century.</p><div data-attr-viewport-monitor="inline-recirc" class="inline-recirc-wrapper inline-recirc-observer-target-10 viewport-monitor-anchor"></div><p class="paywall">Some smart young EAs dared to object publicly to longtermism’s primitive and dangerous reasoning. Senior figures in the movement <a data-offer-url="https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/gx7BEkoRbctjkyTme/democratising-risk-or-how-ea-deals-with-critics-1" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/gx7BEkoRbctjkyTme/democratising-risk-or-how-ea-deals-with-critics-1"}" href="https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/gx7BEkoRbctjkyTme/democratising-risk-or-how-ea-deals-with-critics-1" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">tried</a> to suppress their criticisms, saying that any critiques of central EA figures might threaten future funding. This final phase of EA is where things got genuinely odd.</p><p class="paywall">What’s good in longtermism isn’t new, and what’s new isn’t good. Sages from Gautama Buddha to Jeremy Bentham have encouraged us to aim at the welfare of all sentient creatures. What the longtermists add is the party trick of assigning probabilities to everything. Ord, in his <a data-offer-url="https://theprecipice.com/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://theprecipice.com/"}" href="https://theprecipice.com/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">longtermist book</a>, puts the odds of humanity suffering an existential catastrophe in this century at just under 17 percent.</p><p class="paywall">What MacAskill adds is, again, an amusing lack of humility. His own longtermist book sees him expounding on how we must “structure global society” and “safeguard civilization.” On averting nuclear war, fighting deadly pathogens, and choosing the values to guide humanity’s future, MacAskill claims to know what the world must do.</p><aside aria-hidden="true" class="PullQuoteEmbedWrapper-sc-EoVjf kgVYDs"><div class="PullQuoteDecorativeBorder-sc-iUyOLj jyfYFL"></div><div class="PullQuoteEmbedContent-sc-kTcfhx dzGCEG"><p class="paywall">At their best, EAs are well-meaning people who aspire to rigorous analysis. But EA doesn’t always bring out their best.</p></div></aside><p class="paywall">In other words, we’re still in the land of precise guesses built on weak evidence, but now the stakes are higher and the numbers are distant probabilities. Longtermism lays bare that the EAs’ method is really a way to maximize on looking clever while minimizing on expertise and accountability. Even if the thing you gave a 57 percent chance of happening never happens, you can still claim you were right. These expected value pronouncements thus fit the most philosophically rigorous definition of <a href="https://press.princeton.edu/books/hardcover/9780691122946/on-bullshit">bullshit</a>.</p><p class="paywall">Moreover, if applying expected value thinking to aid is dodgy, applying it to the remote future gets downright supervillainous. When you truly believe that your job is to save hundreds of billions of future lives, you’re rationally required to <a data-offer-url="https://www.project-syndicate.org/commentary/ethical-implications-of-focusing-on-extinction-risk-by-peter-singer-2021-10" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.project-syndicate.org/commentary/ethical-implications-of-focusing-on-extinction-risk-by-peter-singer-2021-10"}" href="https://www.project-syndicate.org/commentary/ethical-implications-of-focusing-on-extinction-risk-by-peter-singer-2021-10" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">sacrifice countless current lives</a> to do it. Remember SBF’s wager: A longtermist must risk the extinction of humanity on a coin flip, double or nothing, over and over again. MacAskill <a data-offer-url="https://80000hours.org/articles/harmful-career/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://80000hours.org/articles/harmful-career/"}" href="https://80000hours.org/articles/harmful-career/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">sometimes</a> tries to escape this murderous logic with bullet-pointed musings about why violating rights is almost never the best way of creating a better world. In his longtermist book, he makes this case in a few wan paragraphs. But you can’t disown your party trick the moment before it breaks the punch bowl.</p><p class="paywall">Despite its daffiness and its dangers, longtermism also found a ready-made audience in EA’s aspiring heroes. (“You Can Shape the Course of History” is the name of a chapter in MacAskill’s longtermist book.) At their best, EAs are well-meaning people who aspire to rigorous analysis. But EA doesn’t always bring out their best. If nerdy young adults see that they can get money or status or sex by intoning on Very Important Things while pulling numbers out of their pants, at least some will start pulling. All the usual hierarchical effects of in-groups will kick in, like groupthink and bullying (and, tragically, the alleged <a href="https://time.com/6252617/effective-altruism-sexual-harassment/">abuse of young EA women</a>).</p></div></div></div><div class="GridItem-buujkM fVLMby grid--item grid-layout__aside"><div class="StickyBoxWrapper-jfYBuk fifekH sticky-box"><div Math Is Next</div></div></div></a><div class="SummaryItemBylineWrapper-boCfbi hYsZi summary-item__byline-date-icon"><div class="SummaryItemBaseByline-fFbXkY gHgYpX summary-item__byline"><div class="summary-item__byline__content"><div data-testid="BylinesWrapper" class="BylinesWrapper-KIudk cdSbAY bylines"><span class="BylineWrapper-jWHrLH eedAre byline bylines__byline" data-testid="BylineWrapper" itemProp="author" itemType="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemProp="name" class="BylineNamesWrapper-jbHncj fuDQVo"><span data-testid="BylineName" class="BylineName-kwmrLn cYaBcc byline__name"><span class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd BaseText-ewhhUZ BylinePreamble-iJolpQ iUEiRd bsrfLw gnILss byline__preamble">By </span>Reece Rogers</span></span></span></div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li class="AsideAdListItem-fTYGpp lmohmA hide-aside-ad"><div class="AdWrapper-dQtivb fZrssQ RecircMostPopularSummaryItem-jQxxiw ghmKWT ad ad--aside"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--aside" data-node-id="zt02ns"></div></div></li></ul><div class="RecircMostPopularFooter-enPjgs knSlyA"></div></div></div></div><div class="StickyBoxPlaceholder-grPmrg dxAvXx"></div></div></div></div><div data-testid="RowWrapper" class="BaseWrap-sc-gjQpdd RowWrapper-UmqTg iUEiRd HEhan full-bleed-ad row-mid-content-ad"><div class="StickyMidContentAdWrapper-fSBzwl drzyIa ad-stickymidcontent"><div class="AdWrapper-dQtivb fZrssQ ad ad--mid-content should-hold-space"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--mid-content" data-node-id="gpjdw9"></div></div></div></div><div class="GridWrapper-cAzTTK sjrqk grid grid-margins grid-items-2 ArticlePageChunksGrid-hfxaau eSqXkM grid-layout--adrail narrow wide-adrail"><div class="GridItem-buujkM stRKV grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class="BodyWrapper-kufPGa dYWmGR body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p class="paywall">SBF also bankrolled longtermism lavishly. He put MacAskill and other EAs at the head of the <a data-offer-url="https://twitter.com/willmacaskill/status/1498370523348283399?lang=en" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://twitter.com/willmacaskill/status/1498370523348283399?lang=en"}" href="https://twitter.com/willmacaskill/status/1498370523348283399?lang=en" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">Future Fund</a>, meant to rescue humanity from “existential risks” like psychotic robots and planet-killing asteroids. The EAs got from SBF more than they’d ever dreamed: <a data-offer-url="https://www.bitdegree.org/crypto/news/ftx-announced-1-billion-future-fund-for-startup-projects" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.bitdegree.org/crypto/news/ftx-announced-1-billion-future-fund-for-startup-projects"}" href="https://www.bitdegree.org/crypto/news/ftx-announced-1-billion-future-fund-for-startup-projects" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">a billion dollars</a> to save the world. But SBF also turned into their undoing. The EAs at the Future Fund had been <a href="https://time.com/6262810/sam-bankman-fried-effective-altruism-alameda-ftx/">warned for years about SBF</a>. The revelation of his enormous financial frauds crashed the fund and decisively ended the EAs’ pose of being experts on risk. As the economist Tyler Cowen remarked on <a data-offer-url="https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2022/11/a-simple-point-about-existential-risk.html" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2022/11/a-simple-point-about-existential-risk.html"}" href="https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2022/11/a-simple-point-about-existential-risk.html" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">the Future Fund and SBF</a>:</p><blockquote class="BlockquoteEmbedWrapper-sc-SdiGL gzzTVu paywall blockquote-embed"><div class="BlockquoteEmbedContent-esRbGs dqgvoS blockquote-embed__content"><p>Hardly anyone associated with Future Fund saw the existential risk to … the Future Fund, even though they were as close to it as one could possibly be. I am thus skeptical about their ability to predict existential risk more generally, and for systems that are far more complex and also far more distant. And, it turns out, many of the real sources of existential risk boil down to hubris and human frailty.</p></div></blockquote><p class="paywall">Pungent in theory, ruinous in practice. What more proof could a rational person need?</p><div data-attr-viewport-monitor="inline-recirc" class="inline-recirc-wrapper inline-recirc-observer-target-11 viewport-monitor-anchor"></div><p class="paywall"><span class="lead-in-text-callout">The billionaires have</span> bought a lot of brains: Many people in Silicon Valley and around the world now call themselves effective altruists. Is there any way they might become Responsible Adults?</p><p class="paywall">Some tech moguls may be unreachable. So many of them seem to be aging children, trying to play <em>Minecraft</em> with our world. They can always buy the tongues that tell them they’re right.</p><p class="paywall">We might have more hope for some EA leaders. Ord now <a data-offer-url="https://80000hours.org/podcast/episodes/toby-ord-perils-of-maximising-good/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://80000hours.org/podcast/episodes/toby-ord-perils-of-maximising-good/"}" href="https://80000hours.org/podcast/episodes/toby-ord-perils-of-maximising-good/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">says</a> he has found a math proof that requires caution about “doing the most good.” Karnofsky has <a data-offer-url="https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/T975ydo3mx8onH3iS/ea-is-about-maximization-and-maximization-is-perilous" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/T975ydo3mx8onH3iS/ea-is-about-maximization-and-maximization-is-perilous"}" href="https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/T975ydo3mx8onH3iS/ea-is-about-maximization-and-maximization-is-perilous" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">worried aloud</a> that EAs don’t know what the hell they’re doing. More transparency from them would help to build trust. If GiveWell is going to keep its pitch, it should pair every “lives saved” guess with a “lives ended” guess, and it should declare all of its uncertainties up front. Philosophers like MacAskill should publish complete accounts of all the money that has been spent on them and why they thought this was for humanity’s eternal good.</p><p class="paywall">Yet transparency isn’t accountability. SBF’s company is being forced to return money to the investors who were misled. What should GiveWell and the institutions of EA do?</p><p class="paywall">Will GiveWell empower any poor people that it might have harmed to file a grievance? And what will it say to all the donors who took its pitches literally? What about the young people who relied on the EA counseling service to go into a career that the service will <a href="https://time.com/6204627/effective-altruism-longtermism-william-macaskill-interview/">no longer recommend</a> for them? Will they at least get an apology?</p></div></div></div><div class="GridItem-buujkM fVLMby grid--item grid-layout__aside"><div class="StickyBoxWrapper-jfYBuk fifekH sticky-box"><div data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p class="paywall">My real hope is for the young people I know who truly want to work for a better world. They’re craving to do something meaningful, like poverty relief or pandemic preparation or AI safety. That’s so admirable, and they’re so impressive. I hope they’ll move into positions of real responsibility. When they get there, what should their philosophy be?</p><p class="paywall">My thought is that what they need first is not so much a philosophy as a good look into the eyes of the people who might be affected by their decisions. That’s what changed my path in Bali—a sense of the reality of others, whose lives are just as valuable as our own. But even that may not be enough for my students in their future jobs when they’re busy making big decisions every day. Here are two tests that any of us can do to keep ourselves accountable.</p><p class="paywall">Call the first the “dearest test.” When you have some big call to make, sit down with a person very dear to you—a parent, partner, child, or friend—and look them in the eyes. Say that you’re making a decision that will affect the lives of many people, to the point that some strangers might be hurt. Say that you believe that the lives of these strangers are just as valuable as anyone else’s. Then tell your dearest, “I believe in my decisions, enough that I’d still make them even if one of the people who could be hurt was you.”</p><div data-attr-viewport-monitor="inline-recirc" class="inline-recirc-wrapper inline-recirc-observer-target-12 viewport-monitor-anchor"></div><p class="paywall">Or you can do the “mirror test.” Look into the mirror and describe what you’re doing that will affect the lives of other people. See whether you can tell yourself, with conviction, that you’re willing to be one of the people who is hurt or dies because of what you’re now deciding. Be accountable, at least, to yourself.</p><p class="paywall">Some EAs may still tell themselves that their lives are more important than other people’s lives because of all the good they will do for the world. For anyone who thinks like that, be accountable for those convictions. Tell your dearest exactly how many human lives you think your own life is worth. Publish your “gearing ratio” on your website, and open it for comments. Add the number of people that you calculate you’ve killed already.</p><p class="paywall">My friend Aaron is a fine philosopher and a lifelong surfer. A dozen years ago, he made it to Indonesia and traveled up from a beach on Nias to villages near Lagundri Bay. He has now been back many times and has built up relationships, including one with a local leader named Damo. Aaron and Damo have become close, and they talk a lot. Aaron knows he’ll never be part of the island, that it’s not his life. But when Damo persuaded his village to put in water tanks and toilets, Aaron volunteered to help with planning. When Aaron got an advance on a book contract, the money went with him on his yearly trip to the island.</p><p class="paywall">No billionaires, no hype, no heroes. Aaron is trying his best to shift his power to Damo and to the people on the island. Aaron will talk about the island if you ask him, but he never brags. And he’s accountable to the people there—in the way all of us are accountable to the real, flesh-and-blood humans we love.</p><p class="paywall"><em>Updated 3/28/2024, 3:30 EDT: This article has been updated to reflect the results of Sam Bankman-Fried's sentencing hearing.</em></p><hr class="paywall"/><p class="paywall"><em>Source images: Getty Images; Ulysses Ortega</em></p><p class="paywall"><em>Let us know what you think about this article. Submit a letter to the editor at</em> <em><a href="mailto:mail@wired.com">mail@wired.com</a>.</em></p></div></div></div><div class="GridItem-buujkM fVLMby grid--item grid-layout__aside"><div
